title: Using URL Query Params in Nuxt 3
description: Use Nuxt3's useRoute function to use URL parameters to determine state.

children.value: This is a continuation of my previous
on how to set query parameters in Nuxt 3. We'll be continuing with the code written there so make sure you check it out.
We left off with our URL looking like
. This is nice but contained a few cases that are less than ideal.
Because the URL parameter is being updated using our input's v-model, if the page is refreshed, we lose that local state and the value stored in
for most of its routing logic.
In our example, we are using the Composition API, one of the new features built into Nuxt 3.
In order to get our route, we use bring
so we can chose to be explicit or implicit.
Having our route unlocks all of the benefits of
, including access to our query params!
With access to our route, we can check the query variable (what's after the = in
I now use this logic alongside a
Now, every time the page is navigated to or refreshed, our
will contain the parameter's value. Otherwise, it'll be an empty string.

props.code:
<!-- pages/example.vue -->
<template>
  <input v-model="twitchStreamer" />
</template>

<script>
  setup() {
    const route = useRoute()
    const router = useRouter()
    const twitchStreamer = ref(route.query.streamer ? route.query.streamer : '')

    watch(twitchStreamer, (twitchStreamer, previous) => {
      router.push({
        path: '/test',
        query: { streamer: twitchStreamer },
      })
    })

    return { twitchStreamer }
</script>

children.value:
<!-- pages/example.vue -->
<template>
  <input v-model="twitchStreamer" />
</template>

<script>
  setup() {
    const route = useRoute()
    const router = useRouter()
    const twitchStreamer = ref(route.query.streamer ? route.query.streamer : '')

    watch(twitchStreamer, (twitchStreamer, previous) => {
      router.push({
        path: '/test',
        query: { streamer: twitchStreamer },
      })
    })

    return { twitchStreamer }
</script>

children.value: VueJS custom events are a great way to communicate between child and parent components.
I was recently was in need of a way to pass more than one value from child to parent within a single custom event. The
do not provide any example showcasing this and instead I needed to refer to some comments within a Stack Overflow thread.
To emit more than one parameter, it's best to pass the data as an object:
VueJS's custom events only accepts two parameters:
The name of the event. In this case, the event name is
Data you want to pass. This can be a string, object, number, boolean, or function.
Access the parameters from the parent component using an event listener:
event from the child component. This event can be captured within the parent component where the child is rendered using the
@success calls the onSuccess method when success is emitted from the child component.
The username and message params are destructured from the object passed into the success emit and are now usable within the onSuccuss function to do as you please.
It took me a little while to find the solution to this problem, so I figured it was best to document it within a blog post for others to benefit from.
